title: Support sigma-clipping with pixel splitting
body: As far as I understand the current `sigma_clip_ng` implementation does the clipping before the splitting. If you want both it should be the other way around. `sigma_clip` does in the other way around but it is not supported by the `Worker` class. It also gives a deprecation warning.

title: Worker with sigma-clipping
body:
> I am trying to use sigma_clip_ng as the integrator for my XRD-CT scans and  it does not seem like it is working as intended.
> 
> I modified the existing script with this:
> 
> self.worker = pyFAI.worker.Worker(azimuthalIntegrator=ai,
> extra_options={"thres":2, "error_model":"azimuthal"},
> integrator_name="sigma_clip_ng")
> 
> But when I run it now the terminal warns that "Either 'variance' or 
> 'error_model' is needed for sigma clipping, using Poissonnian model as 
> default!" for every frame, which is rather often when integrating scans 
> with 150k frames.
> 
> So it does not look like the extra options are getting passed on. Do you 
> know what might be going wrong?

Apparently extra_options get reset or at least `error_model` becomes None: thus the bug flag

title: 2D histogram in Python is apparently broken
problem with integrate_radial with csr_ocl
body:
Hi, 
I tried to run a radial integration with the csl_ocl method and I get the following error:
```
  File "<ipython-input-32-af49e0b0ffe6>", line 1, in <module>
    res = ai.integrate_radial(raw, 36, method='csr_ocl')

  File "C:\Program_writable\Anaconda3\envs\pydidas\lib\site-packages\pyFAI\azimuthalIntegrator.py", line 1617, in integrate_radial
    intensity[count == 0] = empty

TypeError: 'numpy.float32' object does not support item assignment
```
Using for example csl works fine. I checked the type and shape of the sum_ and count variables (lines 1612/1613) and they are 
sum with CSR_OCL: ```<class 'numpy.float32'>```
count with CSR_OCL: ```<class 'numpy.float32'>```
sum with CSR: ```<class 'numpy.ndarray'>```
count with CSR: ```<class 'numpy.ndarray'>```

and when I check the shapes of the res.sum and res.count from the integrate2d, they are
with CSR:
res.count.shape (36, 100)
res.sum.shape (36, 100)

and with CSR_OCL
res_ocl.count.shape (3600,)
res_ocl.sum.shape (3600,)

The same is true for LUT and LUT_OCL. The sum over axis -1 then yields a float for the _OCL methods which raises the TypeError.

I would assume this behaviour is a bug? I could reproduce the problem in Windows and Linux. I have looked through the list of the open issues and (judging by name) think this issue has not yet been reported.

title: sg.get_ai() got unexpected keyword argument when using custom detector
body:
I'm trying to setup a notebook to do the calibration based on the tutorial from [https://pyfai.readthedocs.io/en/master/usage/tutorial/Recalib/Recalib_notebook.html](url) using pyFAI `0.19`

At European XFEL, we are using custom detectors that are not yet in the database of pyFAI. They are defined as it's done in the GUI, meaning, with the pixel size and the shape:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4411314/127357507-f59d09d5-2411-4ad6-b374-80bf8764ebc1.png)

I'm able to go through the tutorial and extract several rings using the guessed initial conditions defined previously, but when I try to refine the geometry I'm getting the following error:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4411314/127355527-806b2d18-c496-4a71-a587-1d0a4a10ed42.png)

The single geometry object seems to be correct:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4411314/127355739-57377042-0293-4d32-9f1a-a62d378f9678.png)

The detector used in the tutorial (Pilatus 1M) works as expected with the `0.19` version and the geometry can be refined.

@takluyver 

Edit: I made it work by commenting the line where one pass the `max_shape` argument to the `OrderedDict` object in the `getPyFAI` method of the `Detector` class from the `_common.py` module, as this argument is wipe out anyway when creating the `SingleGeometry` object from the `goniometer` module

title: Many issues in 2D integrators...
body:
In `pyFAI/ext/splitPixelFullCSR.pyx`, the generation of  the LUT in 1D has been checked and we founf those issues which are likely to be present in 2D as well:
- [x] write out of boundaries in the array `outmax` which count the number of pixel in each bin in the case a radial/azimuthal range were given
- [x] Zero division error when calculating the slopes of the boundaries

The errors have been especially complicated to find as they appear only at the destruction of the object.

Won't be fixed for 0.20

title: [multi_geometry] Error model giving values that are too low
body:
I noticed that the MultiGeometry integrate1d method is giving very small error values when using a provided error model (I have not tried it with an array of variances). Looking at the code, in line 156 of multi_geometry.py the sigma2 array is calculated as the sum of the squares of the individual variance arrays, and at the end the returned sigma array is the square root of sigma2 divided by the count. But in the individual AI objects, the returned sigma array is already being divided by the count for that AI. Isn't this in effect doing the normalization by pixel count twice? Doing some quick math it might make more sense to swap line 156:
`sigma2 += (res.sigma ** 2) / monitor`
with:
`sigma2 += ((res.count * res.sigma) ** 2) / monitor`

import time

def chi2_curves(res1, res2):
    """Calculate the Chi2 value for a pair of integrated data"""
    I = res1.intensity
    J = res2.intensity
    l = len(I)
    assert len(J) == l
    sigma_I = res1.sigma
    sigma_J = res2.sigma
    return ((I-J)**2/(sigma_I**2+sigma_J**2)).sum()/(l-1)

def calc_distribution(ai, kwargs, nbins=100, integrator='new'):
    ai.reset()

        results.append(r)

dataset = np.load('test_chi_data.npy')

title: Issue when using rebinning engines outside their "natural" range
body:
Reported by NSLS-II & APS:
Prior of using pyFAI, we are calculating q values. After that we using
the splitBBox.histoBBox2d() with the q range as input.
 
Last week, we run the reduction in a different energy range, leading to
different value ranges for the arguments pos1 and delta_pos1.
And the data reduction start failing when the values for the vertical range
are reaching 3.14 (probably pi), as shown in the pdf file.
 
To go around this problem, I just divide by 10 the range of the input
in splitBBox.histoBBox2d()
and multiply by 10 afterwards and this is working fine.

Is it something you have already observed? And if so, do you have any way
to go around?

title: Nexus detector in PONI files
body:
Apparently the constructor of Nexus detector is not compatible with the geometry.load method which passes the argument "pixel1, pixels2".
This should be made consistent. 

The geometry calls the detector factory at de-serialization and uses Detector.getPyFAI for serialization.

One idea would be to store the detector config with something like:
detector: NexusDetector
detector_config: {"filename": "/path/to/h5"}

It would be great to have a ponifile version as well.

title: Moiré pattern in 2D (Andreas ID13)
body:
I am having problems with the regrouping of intensity of the 
AimuthalIntegrator.integrate2d as I see quite strong Moiré patterns, 
esp. in the background or in datasets that have generally low counts.

It is actually worst for npt_azim, npt_rad in the order of the number of 
pixels that the region of interest I am looking at has. Changing these 
numbers (oversampling) changes the wavelength of the patterns, but they 
don't disappear. I really would not like to under-sample.

The data may be a difficult to make available for reproduction of this 
error as I am reading ROIs out of a larger data-set and generating a 
custom .poni-file for each ROI before setting up the AimuthalIntegrator. 
I have attached some .png images of a ROI out of an Al2O3 dataset on a 
Eiger4M detector, integrated with all the methods available. The images 
are also on the ESRF network /tmp_14_days/moire/...

The ROI and colorbar are the same in each case
(linear [0,500])
and (ypxl_min = 1196, xpxl_min = 80, num_pxl_y = 415, num_pxl_x = 526)
I oversampled arbitrarily by a factor of 3 for y and 2 for x:
(npt_azim = 3.0*num_pxl_y, npt_rad=3.0*num_pxl_x)

Looking at this I think I might have stumbled across a bug in that not 
all "method"s arguments for integrate2d respect a prior setting of
ai.setChiDiscAtZero()
which I really need to do because the peak I am planning to actually 
integrate is close to Chi = -Pi. 'splitpixel' ignores it, 'csr' cuts off 
at -Pi and 'lut' crashes, see Traceback below.

title: Fix peak picking when using matplotlib + numpy 0.12
body:
Matplotlib mouse event contains float, and it was used as is for peak picking.

It was working without problem while numpy < 0.12 was converting float to int autmomatically.
That's not anymore the case for numpy 0.12.

The better thing to do is to cast the matplotlib event to the expected pixel index.

title: Unresolved external symbol isnan on Windows Python 2.7
body:
Here is the compilation log
```
preproc.obj : error LNK2019: unresolved external symbol isnan referenced in function __pyx_fuse_0_4__pyx_f_5pyFAI_3ext_7preproc_c_preproc$omp$1
build\lib.win-amd64-2.7\pyFAI\ext\preproc.pyd : fatal error LNK1120: 1 unresolved externals
```

Our pre-genrated cython file `preproc.c` do not include portable `isnan` function. This function is preprocessed according to the machine which uses cython. Then, regenerating `preproc.c` with cython on the target machine fix the issue.

It would be better to generate/provide a c-header or c-source code taking care of the target (`#if ...`).
